feed.title: Spark NLP
feed.subtitle: High Performance NLP with Apache Spark

entry.title: Financial Business Item Binary Classifier
entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the business item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

other, business

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")

useEmbeddings = UniversalSentenceEncoder.pretrained() \
    .setInputCols("document") \
    .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("finclf_business_item", "en", "finance/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    useEmbeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[business]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[business]|

Model Information

Model Name: finclf_business_item
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Finance 1.0.0+
License: Licensed
Edition: Official
Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings]
Output Labels: [category]
Language: en
Size: 22.6 MB

References

Weak labelling on documents from Edgar database

Benchmarking

              precision    recall  f1-score   support

    business       0.92      0.89      0.91       644
       other       0.90      0.93      0.92       684

    accuracy                           0.91      1328
   macro avg       0.91      0.91      0.91      1328
weighted avg       0.91      0.91      0.91      1328
entry.summary: Description This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the business item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level. If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely: Paragraph splitting (by multiline); Splitting by headers / subheaders; etc. Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above). Predicted Entities other, business Live Demo Open in Colab Download How to use PythonScalaNLU documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \ .setInputCol("text") \ .setOutputCol("document") useEmbeddings = UniversalSentenceEncoder.pretrained() \ .setInputCols("document") \ .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings") docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("finclf_business_item", "en", "finance/models")\ .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\ .setOutputCol("category") nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[ documentAssembler, useEmbeddings, docClassifier]) df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text") model = nlpPipeline.fit(df) result = model.transform(df) Results +-------+ | result| +-------+ |[business]| |[other]| |[other]| |[business]| Model Information Model Name: finclf_business_item Compatibility: Spark NLP for Finance 1.0.0+ License: Licensed Edition: Official Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings] Output Labels: [category] Language: en Size: 22.6 MB References Weak labelling on documents from Edgar database Benchmarking precision recall f1-score support business 0.92 0.89 0.91 644 other 0.90 0.93 0.92 684 accuracy 0.91 1328 macro avg 0.91 0.91 0.91 1328 weighted avg 0.91 0.91 0.91 1328

entry.title: Financial Controls procedures Item Binary Classifier

link.title: Financial Controls procedures Item Binary Classifier

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the controls_procedures item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

other, controls_procedures

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")

useEmbeddings = UniversalSentenceEncoder.pretrained() \
    .setInputCols("document") \
    .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("finclf_controls_procedures_item", "en", "finance/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    useEmbeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[controls_procedures]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[controls_procedures]|

Model Information

Model Name: finclf_controls_procedures_item
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Finance 1.0.0+
License: Licensed
Edition: Official
Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings]
Output Labels: [category]
Language: en
Size: 22.4 MB

References

Weak labelling on documents from Edgar database

Benchmarking

                     precision    recall  f1-score   support

controls_procedures       0.94      0.93      0.94        86
              other       0.94      0.95      0.94        92

           accuracy                           0.94       178
          macro avg       0.94      0.94      0.94       178
       weighted avg       0.94      0.94      0.94       178

entry.title: Financial Equity Item Binary Classifier
entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the equity item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

other, equity

Download

     .setInputCol("text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")

useEmbeddings = UniversalSentenceEncoder.pretrained() \
    .setInputCols("document") \
    .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("finclf_equity_item", "en", "finance/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")

    useEmbeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

|[other]|

weighted avg       0.84      0.84      0.84       133

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the executives_compensation item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

Download

     .setInputCol("text") \

    .setInputCols("document") \

    useEmbeddings,

df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)

               accuracy                           0.93       187
              macro avg       0.93      0.93      0.93       187
           weighted avg       0.93      0.93      0.93       187

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the executives item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

other, executives

Download

     .setInputCol("text") \

    .setInputCols("document") \

    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")

    documentAssembler, 
    useEmbeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[executives]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[executives]|

Model Information

Model Name: finclf_executives_item
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Finance 1.0.0+
License: Licensed

Benchmarking

       other       0.98      0.96      0.97        45

    accuracy                           0.97        91
   macro avg       0.97      0.97      0.97        91
weighted avg       0.97      0.97      0.97        91

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the exhibits item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Download

     .setInputCol("text") \

    .setInputCols("document") \

link.title: Financial Financial conditions Item Binary Classifier

Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

entry.title: Financial Financial statements Item Binary Classifier

link.title: Financial Financial statements Item Binary Classifier

entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the financial_statements item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

other, financial_statements

Download

How to use

documentAssembler = DocumentAssembler() \
     .setInputCol("text") \
     .setOutputCol("document")

useEmbeddings = UniversalSentenceEncoder.pretrained() \
    .setInputCols("document") \
    .setOutputCol("sentence_embeddings")

docClassifier = ClassifierDLModel().pretrained("finclf_financial_statements_item", "en", "finance/models")\
    .setInputCols(["sentence_embeddings"])\
    .setOutputCol("category")
    
nlpPipeline = Pipeline(stages=[
    documentAssembler, 
    useEmbeddings,
    docClassifier])
 
df = spark.createDataFrame([["YOUR TEXT HERE"]]).toDF("text")
model = nlpPipeline.fit(df)
result = model.transform(df)

Results

+-------+
| result|
+-------+
|[financial_statements]|
|[other]|
|[other]|
|[financial_statements]|

Model Information

Model Name: finclf_financial_statements_item
Compatibility: Spark NLP for Finance 1.0.0+
License: Licensed
Edition: Official
Input Labels: [sentence_embeddings]
Output Labels: [category]
Language: en
Size: 22.6 MB

        weighted avg       0.91      0.90      0.90      2458

To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level. If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely: Paragraph splitting (by multiline); Splitting by headers / subheaders; etc. Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. entry.content:
Description

This model is a Binary Classifier (True, False) for the form_10k_summary item type of 10K Annual Reports. To use this model, make sure you provide enough context as an input. Adding Sentence Splitters to the pipeline will make the model see only sentences, not the whole text, so it’s better to skip it, unless you want to do Binary Classification as sentence level.

If you have big financial documents, and you want to look for clauses, we recommend you to split the documents using any of the techniques available in our Spark NLP for Finance Workshop Tokenization & Splitting Tutorial (link here), namely:

  • Paragraph splitting (by multiline);
  • Splitting by headers / subheaders;
  • etc.

Take into consideration the embeddings of this model allows up to 512 tokens. If you have more than that, consider splitting in smaller pieces (you can also check the same tutorial link provided above).

Predicted Entities

Download

     .setInputCol("text") \
